Description: Fragment from body-shoulder area of North Ionian closed pottery vessel, perhaps an oinochoe. White slip. Inside reserved; exterior: animal frieze on shoulder, rear leg of feline and large rosettes with scant incision; maeander band below, between bands with added red bands lined in white.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by British School at Athens. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Fabric similar to British School at Athens un-numbered sherd, (Smith 2009, p.348 no. 4 fig. 4. Kardara places this fragment in her 'mixed technique' style (193, 199-248) and for the attribution see her 222-8 and 3-4 cf. Walter Karydi 1973 143 no. 895 (Berlin 2939 from Rhodes) and pl. 111 (paw) and 143 no. 918 and pl. 112 (shoulder); CVA Oxford 2 (9) pl. 4 no.45 (inv. G119.40) from Naukratis is similar and see 78 (Camiran style). CVA Cambridge 2 (11) pl. 18 nos 33 and 44 (inv. Nos. N.94-6, 237 and 94-5, N. 226 are also similar (Camiran). Fairbanks 1928, 109 no. 320.3 and 8 a-b and pl 34, belonging to large kraters from Naukratis. For the lion as a subject in the Wild Goat Style see Kardara 1963, 15-3 and 260-1; Kerschner and Schlotzhauer 2005, 16 and 24. T.J. Smith, "East Greek Pottery in the Collection of the British School at Athens", BSA 104, 2009, 348, fig. 5
The number '6' is written in ink on the interior surface of the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Smith 2009 / East Greek Pottery in the Collection of the British School at Athens (p. 348, no. 5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.642)
